conclusion: To determine the amount of heat exchanged between the cyclic gas and the external environment during the ABCDA cycle, we need to analyze each segment of the cycle and apply the first law of thermodynamics.
The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy (ΔU) of a system is equal to the heat added to the system (Q) minus the work done by the system (W): ΔU = Q - W.

For an ideal gas, the internal energy depends only on temperature. Since the cycle is cyclic, the initial and final states are the same, meaning the internal energy change over the entire cycle is zero (ΔU = 0).
The heat exchanged (Q) is equal to the work done (W) over the cycle: Q = W.
Segment AB is an isothermal expansion at constant temperature T0.

premise: Segment AB is isothermal at T0
conclusion: Work done in segment AB: W_AB = P1V1 ln(V2/V1).
Segment BC is an isobaric expansion at constant pressure P2.

premise: Segment BC is isobaric at P2
conclusion: Work done in segment BC: W_BC = P2 (V2 - V1).
Segment CD is an isothermal compression at constant temperature T0.

premise: Segment CD is isothermal at T0
conclusion: Work done in segment CD: W_CD = -P1V1 ln(V2/V1).
Segment DA is an isobaric compression at constant pressure P1.

premise: Segment DA is isobaric at P1
conclusion: Work done in segment DA: W_DA = -P1 (V1 - V2).
Total work done in the cycle: W_total = W_AB + W_BC + W_CD + W_DA.

premise: Expressions for work done in each segment
conclusion: W_total = P1V1 ln(V2/V1) + P2 (V2 - V1) - P1V1 ln(V2/V1) - P1 (V1 - V2).
